description: From the post-Classical Latin monotonus (“unvarying in tone”) or its etymon the Ancient Greek μονότονος (monótonos, “steady”, “unwavering”); compare cognate adjectives, namely the French monotone, the German monoton, the Italian monotono, and the Spanish monótono, as well as the slightly earlier English noun monotony and adjective monotonical.

adjectives.description: monotone (comparative more monotone, superlative most monotone)

entries.meaning: (of speech or a sound) Having a single unvaried pitch.
examples: The prominence of the syllables is more monotone than in English, the intonation of the latter having a larger variation of stressed and unstressed syllables.

entries.meaning: A single unvaried tone of speech or a sound.
examples: When Tima felt like her parents were treating her like a servant, she would speak in monotone and act as though she were a robot.

entries.meaning: A piece of writing in one strain throughout.

verbs.description: monotone (third-person singular simple present monotones, present participle monotoning, simple past and past participle monotoned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To speak in a monotone.
